title: Redox Noninnocent Nature of Acridine-Based Pincer Complexes of 3d Metals and C–C Bond Formation

reactions.text: For example, complex 1 reacts with H2 in the presence of KOH to form complex 2, in which the central acridine ring is dearomatized (Scheme 1A). According to DFT calculations, the transformation from 1 to 2 occurs via the Ru(0) complex I, which undergoes oxidative addition of H2 to form the Ru(II) complex II. Hydride transfer from the metal center of complex II to the C9 position of the acridine ligand results in the formation of the dearomatized complex 2′ (Scheme 1B). Similarly, complex 1 also reacts with NH3 to form complex 3, in which the central ring of the acridine ligand is dearomatized by a hydride transfer from Ru to the C9 position of the acridine ligand (Scheme 1A).

For example, complex 1 reacts with H2 in the presence of KOH to form complex 2, in which the central acridine ring is dearomatized (Scheme 1A). According to DFT calculations, the transformation from 1 to 2 occurs via the Ru(0) complex I, which undergoes oxidative addition of H2 to form the Ru(II) complex II. Hydride transfer from the metal center of complex II to the C9 position of the acridine ligand results in the formation of the dearomatized complex 2′ (Scheme 1B). Similarly, complex 1 also reacts with NH3 to form complex 3, in which the central ring of the acridine ligand is dearomatized by a hydride transfer from Ru to the C9 position of the acridine ligand (Scheme 1A).

For example, complex 1 reacts with H2 in the presence of KOH to form complex 2, in which the central acridine ring is dearomatized (Scheme 1A). According to DFT calculations, the transformation from 1 to 2 occurs via the Ru(0) complex I, which undergoes oxidative addition of H2 to form the Ru(II) complex II. Hydride transfer from the metal center of complex II to the C9 position of the acridine ligand results in the formation of the dearomatized complex 2′ (Scheme 1B). Similarly, complex 1 also reacts with NH3 to form complex 3, in which the central ring of the acridine ligand is dearomatized by a hydride transfer from Ru to the C9 position of the acridine ligand (Scheme 1A).

Reaction of the ligand L with [Ni(H2O)6](BF4)2 in acetonitrile resulted in the formation of the dicationic Ni(II) complex 6 (Scheme 2). A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complex 6 showed a square-planar geometry around the nickel center with one acetonitrile coordinated to the metal center and two BF4 anions present to balance the charge (Figure S33). In order to reduce Ni(II) to Ni(I), we treated complex 6 with Na/Hg.

The two acridine rings were found to be partially overlapping in a staggered conformation with a C5–C7–C44–C45 torsion angle of 46° and the hydrogen atom of the newly formed C–C bond positioned with a torsion angle of 44°. We presume that reduction of complex 6 by Na/Hg results in one-electron transfer to the acridine ligand, the electron being mostly localized at the electrophilic C9 acridine position, leading to the observed dimerization to form complex 7.

Treatment of CoCl2 with the ligand (L) in THF (12 h) at 298 K resulted in the formation of complex 8 in 92% yield (Scheme 3A and Figure S35). The Chirik group and we have previously reported Co(II) complexes of lutidine-based PNP, PNN, and PNNH ligands and their reduction by NaBEt3H to form a Co(I) complex via liberation of H2 (Scheme 3B). Interestingly, in the case of the acridine ligand, treatment of complex 8 with NaBEt3H resulted in the formation of the new complex 9, as confirmed by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study.

Treatment of CoCl2 with the ligand (L) in THF (12 h) at 298 K resulted in the formation of complex 8 in 92% yield (Scheme 3A and Figure S35). The Chirik group and we have previously reported Co(II) complexes of lutidine-based PNP, PNN, and PNNH ligands and their reduction by NaBEt3H to form a Co(I) complex via liberation of H2 (Scheme 3B). Interestingly, in the case of the acridine ligand, treatment of complex 8 with NaBEt3H resulted in the formation of the new complex 9, as confirmed by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study.

We suggest that complex 9 is formed via the cobalt hydride intermediate III, which generates H2 by homolytic cleavage of Co–H to form an intermediate Co(I) complex that transfers an electron to the acridine ring (complex IV) with the electron localized mainly at the electrophilic C9 position, leading to the observed dimerization via C–C bond formation (C–C length 1.608 Å) (Scheme 3C). The stoichiometric treatment of complex 8 with an equivalent amount of NaBEt3H in the presence of diphenylacetylene afforded cis- and trans-stilbene as the partially hydrogenated products, which may indicate a metal complex mediated role in H radical transfer.

CO bands in the IR spectrum were detected at 1957 (s) and 1897 (s) cm–1. We suggest that the dimer formation occurs via the intermediacy of the Fe(0) complex V, which transforms to the radical VI via electron transfer from Fe(0) to the acridine ligand, the electron being mainly localized on the C9 position, similar to the proposed formation of complexes 7 and 9 (Scheme 4B).

We have now synthesized the manganese complex of the acridine ligand L′. Interestingly, stirring a Et2O solution of the acridine ligand L′ with Mn(CO)5Br at 300 K overnight resulted in two major signals in the 31P{1H} NMR spectrum, one in the region of the free phosphine group (δ 14.5) and another corresponding to the coordinated phosphine (δ 58.8).

Single crystals of the newly formed complex were grown in DCM/Et2O solution. An X-ray diffraction study of the crystals confirmed the structure of the complex as 11 (Figure S38), in which only one phosphine group is bound to the Mn tetracarbonyl bromide fragment, the remaining phosphine and nitrogen donors being free, as also observed by NMR spectroscopy. Heating complex 11 at 80 °C in THF or performing the complexation reaction at 80 °C resulted in formation of a polymeric manganese complex, as also observed earlier by Heren for a related manganese complex (see the Supporting Information). Interestingly, reaction of complex 11 with TlPF6 in acetonitrile at 70 °C resulted in formation of a new complex.

Single crystals of the newly formed complex were grown in DCM/Et2O solution. An X-ray diffraction study of the crystals confirmed the structure of the complex as 11 (Figure S38), in which only one phosphine group is bound to the Mn tetracarbonyl bromide fragment, the remaining phosphine and nitrogen donors being free, as also observed by NMR spectroscopy. Heating complex 11 at 80 °C in THF or performing the complexation reaction at 80 °C resulted in formation of a polymeric manganese complex, as also observed earlier by Heren for a related manganese complex (see the Supporting Information). Interestingly, reaction of complex 11 with TlPF6 in acetonitrile at 70 °C resulted in formation of a new complex.

In our further attempt to study the reactivity of complex 12, we treated complex 12 with 2 equiv of KOtBu in CD3CN at 300 K. 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopy after 15 min showed the complete disappearance of the Mn complex 12, and the NMR spectrum consisting mainly only of a multiplet at δ −143.7 due to the PF6 anion. A red precipitate was obtained, the whole mixture was heated at 80 °C for a period of one hour and the hot CD3CN solution allowed to slowly cool down yielding compound 14 as a red crystalline material suitable for X-ray analysis.
